content:
On 22 January 2026, the Labour Government cancelled Burnley Borough Council's local elections, which had been scheduled for 7 May 2026. Burnley was one of 30 councils across England to have their elections postponed - ostensibly to allow councils to focus on Local Government Reorganisation (LGR).

The decision means that approximately 15 councillors whose terms were due to expire in May 2026 will now remain in office without facing voters until the council is abolished on 31 March 2028. Some of these councillors, last elected in May 2022, will serve almost six years without a democratic mandate.

How It Happened

On 18 December 2025, the Minister for Local Government, Alison McGovern, wrote to 63 councils inviting them to request a postponement of their May 2026 elections if they had concerns about capacity for LGR preparations.

Burnley Council convened special meetings on 13 January 2026 to consider the ministerial letter. The Scrutiny Committee met first at 6:30pm, followed by the Executive at 8pm.

The outcome was remarkable: the Scrutiny Committee recommended proceeding with the elections, but the Executive overruled that recommendation and voted to write to the Government requesting postponement.

Council Leader Afzal Anwar stated the Executive "reluctantly support the postponement," arguing that if most other Lancashire councils with May 2026 elections were being postponed, Burnley should be too - for consistency.

The Executive's justification centred on cost and officer capacity - arguing it would be difficult to run elections while simultaneously preparing for LGR. The cost of a Burnley Borough Council election was estimated at £150,209, based on the 2023/24 figure.

The Labour Government's Role

The power to postpone local elections sits with the Secretary of State. The Labour Government had previously used these powers in February 2025 to postpone elections in nine council areas, and in December 2025 to delay inaugural mayoral elections in four regions from May 2026 to May 2028.

Of the 30 councils where elections were cancelled on 22-29 January 2026, 19 are Labour-run. This political composition fuelled accusations that the Government was acting out of electoral self-interest - cancelling elections that polling suggested would result in significant Labour losses.

All seven Lancashire councils due to hold elections in May 2026 had their polls cancelled: Blackburn with Darwen, Burnley, Chorley, Hyndburn, Pendle, Preston, and West Lancashire.

The Opposition Response

The Electoral Commission issued a strongly-worded statement expressing disappointment at "both the timing and substance" of the Government's approach. Chief Executive Vijay Rangarajan stated that capacity constraints are not "a legitimate reason for delaying long-planned elections," that "extending existing mandates risks affecting the legitimacy of local decision making," and - critically - that there was "a clear conflict of interest in asking existing Councils to decide how long it will be before they are answerable to voters."

Reform UK launched a judicial review against the Government. The case - Reform UK Party Limited v Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government - was listed for a two-day hearing on 19-20 February 2026 at the Divisional Court. Reform argued the postponements discourage candidates from standing and undermine democratic campaigns.

A public petition calling for the removal of the power to cancel local elections reached 150,814 signatures, triggering a Parliamentary debate scheduled for 2 March 2026.

Pendle's Liberal Democrat leader David Whipp described the cancellation as "a denial of democracy," warning that "those arguing that money could be better spent are on thin ice - it's a slippery slope once you begin to put a price on democracy."

Even Labour backbencher Florence Eshalomi MP, chair of the Commons Housing, Communities and Local Government Committee, warned that "democracy is not an inefficiency that should be cut out."

The Democratic Deficit

Burnley Borough Council operates on an election-by-thirds cycle, with approximately one-third of the council's 45 seats contested each year. The cancellation means:

  • No Burnley Borough Council elections will ever be held again - the council will be abolished by April 2028 under LGR
  • Councillors last elected in May 2022 will serve until March 2028 - nearly six years without facing voters
  • The next time residents can vote for local councillors will be at shadow authority elections in May 2027, for the new unitary council - not for Burnley Borough Council
  • 15 councillors who would have faced voters in May 2026 will now remain in post without having to account for their record

The Cost Argument Doesn't Add Up

Proponents of cancellation cited the £150,209 cost of running an election. But this argument raises uncomfortable questions:

  • If elections can be cancelled to save £150,000, what other democratic processes could be cut on cost grounds?
  • Burnley Council has spent at least £37,000 on LGR consultants already - and transition costs typically run into millions. Is £150,000 for an election really the saving that matters?
  • The council's total annual budget is £18.7 million. The election cost represents less than 1% of one year's spending
  • As the Electoral Commission noted, there is a "clear conflict of interest" in councillors - who benefit from the postponement - making the decision

Burnley's Scrutiny Committee Got It Right

Burnley's own Scrutiny Committee - the body specifically tasked with holding the Executive to account - recommended proceeding with the elections. The Executive chose to overrule this recommendation.

This raises questions about how seriously the scrutiny function is taken at Burnley Borough Council. If the Executive can simply ignore its Scrutiny Committee's recommendations on a matter as fundamental as whether residents should have the right to vote, what is the point of the scrutiny process?

Timeline

  • 18 December 2025: Minister writes to 63 councils inviting postponement requests
  • 13 January 2026: Burnley Scrutiny Committee recommends elections proceed; Executive overrules and requests postponement
  • 22 January 2026: Secretary of State Steve Reed cancels elections in 29 council areas, including Burnley
  • 29 January 2026: Pendle becomes the 30th council to have elections cancelled
  • 19-20 February 2026: Reform UK judicial review hearing at the Divisional Court
  • 2 March 2026: Parliamentary debate on petition with 150,814+ signatures

The cancellation of democratic elections - whether justified by LGR or not - represents a significant moment in Burnley's civic history. Residents who disagree with the decisions their councillors make between now and March 2028 will have no ballot box recourse. The question of whether that is an acceptable trade-off for saving less than 1% of the council's annual budget is one that voters were never given the chance to answer.

Sources: Burnley Borough Council Executive and Scrutiny Committee meetings, 13 January 2026; House of Commons statement by Steve Reed MP, 22 January 2026; Electoral Commission statement; Reform UK judicial review filing; Parliament petition #747234; Burnley Express, Lancashire Evening Post, and Blog Preston reporting.
